title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: On February 10, the impeachment managers began to present their case.{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Melissa Macaya, Meg Wagner, Veronica Rocha, Melissa Mahtani and Mike Hayes|date=2021-02-10|title=Trump impeachment trial: Live coverage and news from the Senate|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-10-2021/index.html|access-date=2021-02-10|website=CNN|language=en}}

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: A Hill/HarrisX poll released on February 10 found that 52% of Americans favored Conviction with 48% opposed.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Schulte|first=Gabriela|date=2021-02-10|title=Poll: 52 percent say Senate should convict Trump|url=https://thehill.com/hilltv/what-americas-thinking/538297-poll-52-percent-say-senate-should-convict-trump|access-date=2021-02-11|website=TheHill|language=en}}</ref>

A [[Vox (website)|Vox]]/[[Data for Progress]] poll released on February 10th found that that 12% of Republicans supported conviction compared to 82% of Democrats and 52% of independents. And that 69% of Republicans said they’d be less likely to vote for a political candidate in their state if that person voted for conviction.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Zhou|first=Li|date=2021-02-10|title=Poll: 69 percent of Republicans are less likely to vote for a senator who convicts Trump|url=https://www.vox.com/2021/2/10/22276210/trump-impeachment-trial-poll|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: A Hill/HarrisX poll released on February 10 found that 52% of Americans favoredconvictionwith 48% opposed.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Schulte|first=Gabriela|date=2021-02-10|title=Poll: 52 percent say Senate should convict Trump|url=https://thehill.com/hilltv/what-americas-thinking/538297-poll-52-percent-say-senate-should-convict-trump|access-date=2021-02-11|website=TheHill|language=en}}</ref>

A [[Vox (website)|Vox]]/[[Data for Progress]] poll released on February10found that 12% of Republicans supported conviction compared to 82% of Democrats and 52% of independentsandthat 69% of Republicans said they’d be less likely to vote for a political candidate in their state if that person voted for conviction.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Zhou|first=Li|date=2021-02-10|title=Poll: 69 percent of Republicans are less likely to vote for a senator who convicts Trump|url=https://www.vox.com/2021/2/10/22276210/trump-impeachment-trial-poll|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
deleted: Immediately after the end of the first day of the opening arguments, Senator [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]] moved to strike a portion of the prosecution's presentation that included statements attributed to him regarding Trump's call to Senator [[Tommy Tuberville]], saying they were untrue. The objection caught all the senators and Senate parliamentarians by surprise as, under Senate rules, they are forbidden from speaking and must submit questions in writing. The issue temporarily led to confusion as the presiding officer Patrick Leahy and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer sought to clarify the objection and restore order. Raskin agreed to withdraw that part of the presentation, and he and Schumer stated it may or may not be reintroduced the following day. The Senate adjourned thereafter.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Choi|first=Matthew|date=2021-02-11|title=Mike Lee objects to anecdote, prompting a confusing end to 2nd day of Trump trial|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/10/mike-lee-trump-impeachment-468509|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Politico|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|authors=Melissa Macaya, Veronica Rocha, Melissa Mahtani, and Mike Hayes|date=2021-02-10|title=GOP senator objects to impeachment managers' characterization of his words during the Capitol riot|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-10-2021/h_48cc53ae8aed2661c0b7f9df602292e1|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: Immediately after the end of the first day of opening arguments, Senator [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]] invoked an impeachment rule that allows senators to raise questions during the trial, including about the admissibility of evidence.<ref name="proceduralchaos">{{Cite news|last=Cochrane|first=Emily|last2=Broadwater|first2=Luke|date=2021-02-11|title=Day 2 ends in procedural chaos as Senator Mike Lee asks for his name to be struck from the prosecution's arguments.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/10/us/politics/mike-lee.html|access-date=2021-02-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Lee moved to strike a portion of the prosecution's presentation that included characterizations of Trump's documented and reported calls to him and Senator [[Tommy Tuberville]], claiming that they were untrue. The objection caught the senators and Senate parliamentarians by surprise as, under Senate rules, they are not to ask but submit questions in writing. Leahy, who consulted with the Senate parliamentarian, pointed to a rule specific to this impeachment trial that allows the House managers to include evidence not previously in their pre-trial briefs, and denied the request. An outraged Lee demanded an appeal, and [[Joe Manchin]] demanded that Lee explain why the statements were false. The issue temporarily caused confusion as Leahy and Schumer sought to clarify the objection and restore order. Raskin then agreed to withdraw the part of the presentation Lee objected to.<ref name="proceduralchaos" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Choi|first=Matthew|date=2021-02-11|title=Mike Lee objects to anecdote, prompting a confusing end to 2nd day of Trump trial|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/10/mike-lee-trump-impeachment-468509|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-02-11|website=Politico|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|authors=Melissa Macaya, Veronica Rocha, Melissa Mahtani, and Mike Hayes|date=2021-02-10|title=GOP senator objects to impeachment managers' characterization of his words during the Capitol riot|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-10-2021/h_48cc53ae8aed2661c0b7f9df602292e1|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2021-02-11|website=CNN|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
deleted: {{Expand section|date=February 2021|Multiple notable reliable sources have reported on event}}

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: On February 12, a group of 199 legal experts, including prominent conservative lawyers [[Charles Fried]], [[Stuart M. Gerson]], Paul Rosenzweig, and [[Peter Keisler]], issued an letter said that, after the rejection of Trump's jurisdictional challenge, the Senate had an obligation to vote on the merits, contradicting the stance of Senate Republicans who said they would vote against convicting Trump because he was no longer in office. The scholars wrote that, "The former President chose to raise a jurisdictional argument in a motion to dismiss the trial. This body, exercising its considered judgment, determined that the Senate does have jurisdiction to try this case and so resolved the issue. ...  Now that the Senate, as a collegial body, has ruled on the jurisdictional question, individual Senators should respect and honor that determination of the Senate as a body, even if they might have disagreed with it as an initial matter."<ref name=Blake199Experts>Aaron Blake, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/12/199-legal-experts-say-senate-must-not-acquit-trump-over-constitutionality-issue/ 199 legal experts say Senate must not acquit Trump over constitutionality issue], ''Washington Post'' (February 12, 2021).</ref> This echoed an argument the lead House impeachment manager Jamie Raskin had made the preceding date: that the February 9 Senate vote that the Senate had constitutional jurisdiction obliged each Senator to vote "on the facts of what happened."<ref name=Blake199Experts/>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: On February 12, a group of 199 legal experts, including prominent conservative lawyers [[Charles Fried]], [[Stuart M. Gerson]], Paul Rosenzweig, and [[Peter Keisler]], issued an lettersayingthat,becuauseTrump's jurisdictional challengehadbeenrejectedbyamajorityoftheSenate, the Senatehadanobligationtovoteonthemerits:"The former President chose to raise a jurisdictional argument in a motion to dismiss the trial. This body, exercising its considered judgment, determined that the Senate does have jurisdiction to try this case and so resolved the issue. ...  Now that the Senate, as a collegial body, has ruled on the jurisdictional question, individual Senators should respect and honor that determination of the Senate as a body, even if they might have disagreed with it as an initial matter."<ref name=Blake199Experts>Aaron Blake, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/12/199-legal-experts-say-senate-must-not-acquit-trump-over-constitutionality-issue/ 199 legal experts say Senate must not acquit Trump over constitutionality issue], ''Washington Post'' (February 12, 2021).</ref>The letter-writersechoed an argument the lead House impeachment manager Jamie Raskin had made the precedingday:(that the February 9 Senate votedefinitivelyestablishedconstitutional jurisdictionandobliged each Senator to vote "on the facts of what happened") and contradicted  the stance of Senate Republicans who said they would vote against convicting Trump on the procedural ground that he was no longer president.<ref name=Blake199Experts/>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: On February 12, a group of 199 legal experts, including prominent conservative lawyers [[Charles Fried]], [[Stuart M. Gerson]], Paul Rosenzweig, and [[Peter Keisler]], issued an letter saying that,becaseTrump's jurisdictional challenge hadfailed, the Senate had an obligation to vote on the merits: "The former President chose to raise a jurisdictional argument in a motion to dismiss the trial. This body, exercising its considered judgment, determined that the Senate does have jurisdiction to try this case and so resolved the issue. ...  Now that the Senate, as a collegial body, has ruled on the jurisdictional question, individual Senators should respect and honor that determination of the Senate as a body, even if they might have disagreed with it as an initial matter."<ref name=Blake199Experts>Aaron Blake, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/12/199-legal-experts-say-senate-must-not-acquit-trump-over-constitutionality-issue/ 199 legal experts say Senate must not acquit Trump over constitutionality issue], ''Washington Post'' (February 12, 2021).</ref> The letter-writers echoed an argument the lead House impeachment manager Jamie Raskin had made the preceding day: (that the February 9 Senate vote definitively established constitutional jurisdiction and obliged each Senator to vote "on the facts of what happened") and contradicted  the stance of Senate Republicans who said they would vote against convicting Trump on the procedural ground that he was no longer president.<ref name=Blake199Experts/>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: The first question from Schumer and Feinstein was of whether the attack on the Capitol would have happened if not for Trump's conduct. Manager Castro responding by quoting Cheney's statement on Trump's actions. Graham, Cruz, Kevin Cramer, and Roger Marshall submitted a question on whether politicians raising bail for rioters encouraged more rioters, which Castor affirmed.<ref>{{Cite web|last=News|first=A. B. C.|title=Trump impeachment trial live updates: Defense hammers at alleged Dem hypocrisy|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/live-updates/trump-impeachment-trial-live-updates-senate-debate-constitutionality/?id=75741945|access-date=2021-02-12|website=ABC News|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: Bernie Sanders asked both sides whether, in their judgement, Trump lost the 2020 election or if he was repeating the "big lie" that his "landslide election victory" was stolen. Manager Plaskett recalled that Trump lost the popular and electoral vote, and that the DOJ and courts had agreed that all legal votes were acounted and to proceed with the peaceful transfer of power. Van der Veen however refused to answer the question on the basis that his judgement was "irrelevant" to this proceeding and the article of impeachment, causing ruckus in the Senate floor before Leahy restored order.<ref name=":1" />

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: In remarks on the Senate floor after the verdict was reached,  Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who voted for acquittal, said in part:

January 6th was a disgrace. American citizens attacked their own government. They used terrorism to try to stop a specific piece of democratic business they did not like. Fellow Americans beat and bloodied our own police. They stormed the Senate floor. They tried to hunt down the Speaker of the House. They built a gallows and chanted about murdering the Vice President. They did this because they had been fed wild falsehoods by the most powerful man on Earth — because he was angry he’d lost an election. Former President Trump’s actions preceding the riot were a disgraceful dereliction of duty. The House accused the former President of, quote, ‘incitement.’ That is a specific term from the criminal law. Let me put that to the side for one moment and reiterate something I said weeks ago: There is no question that President Trump is practically and morally responsible for provoking the events of that day.https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/13/politics/mitch-mcconnell-acquit-trump/index.htmlhttps://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/remarks/mcconnell-on-impeachment-disgraceful-dereliction-cannot-lead-senate-to-defy-our-own-constitutional-guardrails#:~:text=%E2%80%9CThey%20did%20this%20because%20they,he'd%20lost%20an%20election.&text=%E2%80%9CFormer%20President%20Trump's%20actions%20preceding,%2C%20quote%2C%20'incitement.'

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: January 6th was a disgrace. American citizens attacked their own government. They used terrorism to try to stop a specific piece of democratic business they did not like. Fellow Americans beat and bloodied our own police. They stormed the Senate floor. They tried to hunt down the Speaker of the House. They built a gallows and chanted about murdering the Vice President. They did this because they had been fed wild falsehoods by the most powerful man on Earth — because he was angry he’d lost an election. Former President Trump’s actions preceding the riot were a disgraceful dereliction of duty. The House accused the former President of, quote, ‘incitement.’ That is a specific term from the criminal law. Let me put that to the side for one moment and reiterate something I said weeks ago: There is no question that President Trump is practically and morally responsible for provoking the events of that day.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/13/politics/mitch-mcconnell-acquit-trump/index.html|title=McConnell blames Trump but voted not guilty anyway|first=Alex Rogers, Manu Raju and Jeremy Herb|last=CNN|website=CNN}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/remarks/mcconnell-on-impeachment-disgraceful-dereliction-cannot-lead-senate-to-defy-our-own-constitutional-guardrails#:~:text=%E2%80%9CThey+did+this+because+they,he%27d+lost+an+election.&text=%E2%80%9CFormer+President+Trump%27s+actions+preceding,,+quote,+%27incitement.%27|title=McConnell on Impeachment: “Disgraceful Dereliction” Cannot Lead Senate to “Defy Our Own Constitutional Guardrails” | Republican Leader|website=www.republicanleader.senate.gov}}

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: <!-- A full list of the questions in an easy-to-read format can be found here: [[Draft:Question-and-answer session of the second impeachment trial of Donald Trump]] -->

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: |+Vote on allowing both side to subpoena witnesses for testimony and documents for the trial <ref>{{Cite news|last=Cai|first=Weiyi|last2=Daniel|first2=Annie|last3=Huang|first3=Jon|last4=Lee|first4=Jasmine C.|last5=Parlapiano|first5=Alicia|date=2021-02-13|title=Trump’s Second Impeachment: How the Senate Voted|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/02/13/us/politics/senate-impeachment-live-vote.html|access-date=2021-02-14|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
deleted: Separately from the impeachment trial, Representative [[Liz Cheney]] referenced the "massive criminal investigation" underway focusing on "everyone who was involved" and suggested that Trump could be the subject of a criminal prosecution.<ref>{{cite web|date=February 7, 2021|title=Liz Cheney raises possibility of criminal investigation of Trump for provoking violence|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/feb/07/liz-cheney-criminal-investigation-trump-tweet-mike-pence|access-date=February 9, 2021|website=the Guardian|language=en}}</ref> [[Georgia Secretary of State]] [[Brad Raffensperger]] confirmed that his office had started an investigation into Trump's attempts to overturn the state's election results, including a [[Trump–Raffensperger phone call|phone call]] the former president made to Raffensperger. The Fulton County district attorney, [[Fani Willis]], has also started a criminal investigation into whether Trump should be charged for soliciting election fraud, a violation of Georgia state law.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jason Morris|title=Georgia secretary of state's office launches investigation into Trump's phone call|website=CNN|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/08/politics/georgia-secretary-of-state-trump-investigation/index.html|access-date=February 9, 2021}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
deleted: {{Lead rewrite|date=February 2021|reason=This lead section may lend undue weight to certain ideas, incidents, or controversies. Please help improve it by rewriting it in a balanced fashion that contextualizes different points of view.}}

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: There was a high amount of tension during the verdict. Schumer glared at McConnell when the latter voted to acquit. John Thune looked visibly uncomfortable and nervous the entire time, and Lisa Murkowski glared at him when he whispered "not guilty". Trump's legal team did not expect the number of Republicans voting to convict.{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=What the scene was like in the Senate during the final vote|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_02fa53c381c725fbbf3bfbf9a506be3a|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=Here's how Trump's team reacted to his acquittal|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_21206205d4b1d9a7c71bede13406e864|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}

Schumer blasted the Senate's decision to acquit Trump in a floor speech, calling it "un-American" and insulting to patriots who sacrificed themselves for the counrtry. "There is nothing, nothing more un-American than that ... There is nothing, nothing more antithetical to our democracy... insulting to the generations of Americans patriots who gave their lives to defend our form of government." Schumer vowed that the storming of the Capitol would be Trump's "final terrible legacy" and that that the Republicans who voted to acquit would "live on in infamy, a stain on Donald John Trump that can never, never be washed away".{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=Schumer blasts Trump's acquittal as "un-American"|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_29dc335be2f0a0b37a83d88468cd1cac|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}

Bill Cassidy said the constitution and the country "is more important that any one person" and that he voted to convict Trump "because he is guilty."{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=GOP Sen. Cassidy says he voted to convict Trump because "he is guilty"|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_93ae8b4a03119ff0eb60abdddc054fd0|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}} Susan Collins explained her vote that Trump "incited an insurrection with the purpose of preventing that transfer of power from occurring," saying that Trump's “actions to interfere with the peaceful transition of power – the hallmark of our Constitution and our American democracy – were an abuse of power and constitute grounds for conviction.”{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=GOP Sen. Collins: Trump "incited an insurrection" to prevent "peaceful transfer of authority"|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_ef158d6a55bab37146ad78e94140c251|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}

Trump released a statement following the Senate vote.{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=Here's what Trump said after his second acquittal|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_aec30577edcd95e1584de48b398cf048|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}

Raskin hailed the effort as the "most bipartisan presidential impeachment in the history of the United States" stating that "Trump stormed our House with the mob he incited and we defended our House".{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=By Meg Wagner, Melissa Mahtani, Melissa Macaya and Veronica Rocha|date=2021-02-13|title=Raskin: "We defended our House"|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/h_ec19fa9e22999e4f406772b53f3b864e|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN|language=en}}

Mitch McConnell was widely condemned for his hypocrisy on condemning Trump but voting to acquit regardless on debunked jurisdictional issues. Mitch McConnell was heavily criticized even more so because then-Senate Majority Leader McConnell had maneuvered to block the House from starting the trial before Trump had left office, and then used it as an excuse to not convict him.

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
added: Separately from the impeachment trial, Representative [[Liz Cheney]] referenced the "massive criminal investigation" underway focusing on "everyone who was involved" and suggested that Trump could be the subject of a criminal prosecution.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Pilkington|first=Ed|date=2021-02-07|title=Liz Cheney raises possibility of criminal investigation of Trump for provoking violence|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/feb/07/liz-cheney-criminal-investigation-trump-tweet-mike-pence|access-date=2021-02-15|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> [[Georgia Secretary of State]] [[Brad Raffensperger]] confirmed that his office had started an investigation into Trump's attempts to overturn the state's election results, including a [[Trump–Raffensperger phone call|phone call]] the former president made to Raffensperger. The Fulton County district attorney, [[Fani Willis]], has also started a criminal investigation into whether Trump should be charged for soliciting election fraud, a violation of Georgia state law.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Fausset|first=Richard|last2=Hakim|first2=Danny|date=2021-02-10|title=Georgia Prosecutors Open Criminal Inquiry Into Trump’s Efforts to Subvert Election|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/10/us/politics/trump-georgia-investigation.html|access-date=2021-02-15|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Trump has also faced concerns whether he could be criminally charged by the [[United States Attorney for the District of Columbia|US Attorney for the District of Columbia]] or the [[Attorney General for the District of Columbia|DC attorney general]] for his actions surrounding the Capitol storming.<ref>{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=Kaitlan Collins|title=Trump has privately voiced concern about being charged related to January 6 riot|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/13/politics/trump-concern-charges-january-6/index.html|access-date=2021-02-15|website=CNN}}</ref>

Section 3 of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution]] disqualifies from federal or state office<ref name="3CNN">{{Cite news|last=Wolf|first=Zachary B.|date=2021-01-12|title=What's the 14th Amendment and how does it work?|work=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/11/politics/14th-amendment-explainer/index.html|access-date=2021-02-15}}</ref> anyone who has taken an oath to support the Constitution<ref name="3WaPo">{{cite news|last1=Rosenwald|first1=Michael S.|date=2021-01-12|title=There's an alternative to impeachment or 25th Amendment for Trump, historians say|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2021/01/11/14th-amendment-trump-insurrection-impeachment/|access-date=January 18, 2021}}</ref><ref name="3ABC">{{Cite news|last=Parks|first=MaryAlice|date=2021-01-12|title=Democrats cite rarely used part of 14th Amendment in new impeachment article|language=en|work=[[ABC News]]|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/democrats-cite-rarely-part-constitution-impeachment-article/story?id=75177543|access-date=2021-02-15}}</ref> and either "engaged in insurrection or rebellion" against the Constitution,<ref name="3Reuters">{{cite news|last=Wolfe|first=Jan|date=January 14, 2021|title=Explainer: Impeachment or the 14th Amendment - Can Trump be barred from future office?|work=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-impeachment-explainer/explainer-impeachment-or-the-14th-amendment-can-trump-be-barred-from-future-office-idUSKBN29I356}}</ref> or "given aid to the enemies" of the US.<ref name="3ABA">{{Cite magazine|last=Weiss|first=Debra Cassens|date=2021-01-12|title=Could the 14th Amendment be used to disqualify Trump from office?|url=https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/could-the-14th-amendment-be-used-to-disqualify-trump-from-office|language=en|access-date=2021-02-15|work=[[ABA Journal]]}}</ref> Although the section's text does not explicitly describe how it is invoked, by congressional precedent, disqualification is invoked by a simple majority of both chambers, and can be removed by a supermajority of both chambers.{{r|3Reuters|3ABA}} During the [[second impeachment of Donald Trump]], Section 3 was cited in the Article of Impeachment as part of the basis for barring Trump from holding future office.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Shelby|date=January 14, 2021|title=14th Amendment is the cornerstone of Trump's impeachment. How it works, why it matters|newspaper=Cnet|url=https://www.cnet.com/how-to/14th-amendment-is-the-cornerstone-of-trumps-impeachment-how-it-works-why-it-matters/}}</ref>{{refn|{{Cite web|url=https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/BILLS-117hres24ih/pdf/BILLS-117hres24ih.pdf|title=117TH CONGRESS 1ST SESSION H. RES. 24. Impeaching Donald John Trump, President of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors.}} }} It is disputed whether Section 3 can be used as a potential "alternate path to disqualification [from office]" if the Senate votes to acquit Trump of the impeachment charge.{{r|3WaPo|3Reuters}}<ref>{{Cite web|last=McLaughlin|first=Dan|date=January 12, 2021|title=The Wrong Tool for Punishing Trump|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2021/01/the-wrong-tool-for-punishing-trump/|access-date=January 24, 2021|website=[[National Review]]}}</ref> Democrats such as Richard Blumenthal, Chris Murphy Dick Durbin, and Ben Cardin, have considered invoking Section 3 to bar Trump from holding office again, though such a move would enter uncharted constitutional and legal territory.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Homan|first=Timothy R.|date=2021-01-22|title=Democrats float 14th Amendment to bar Trump from office|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/535467-democrats-float-14th-amendment-to-bar-trump-from-office|access-date=2021-02-15|website=TheHill|language=en}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
deleted: Despite Republican Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] voting to acquit, citing concerns about constitutional jurisdiction, he fully condemned former President Trump on the Senate floor after the impeachment vote, describing Trumps actions as a "disgraceful dereliction of duty" adding, "There is no question that President Trump is practically and morally responsible for provoking the events of that day".<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/remarks/mcconnell-on-impeachment-disgraceful-dereliction-cannot-lead-senate-to-defy-our-own-constitutional-guardrails|title= McConnell on Impeachment: "Disgraceful Dereliction" Cannot Lead Senate to "Defy Our Own Constitutional Guardrails"|website= republicanleader.senate.gov|access-date= February 13, 2021}}</ref>

title: Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump
